intro: Teucrium divaricatum subsp. divaricatum, commonly known as the narrowleaf germander, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to regions of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branching stems and small, opposite leaves that are usually lanceolate in shape. The plant produces clusters of small, tubular flowers that are usually pink or purple, blooming from late spring to early autumn. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or grassy habitats. Its aromatic leaves and medicinal properties have made it historically significant in traditional herbal medicine.
